FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 24, 1886.

THE GLOBE ON MR. DEWEY'S

The Globe of August 20th says—

"Mr. Dewey has been visited by his proposals by nearly everybody with whom he spoke, who, said he, would, if elected, be able to settle the question by means of his contracting friends."

And when the temperature is about 75°, and the wind is blowing from the southeast, the odds are that Mr. Dewey will repeat his broadcast charges. We do not know how much of this money will find its way into this district, but certainly it will be very popular, so the water is being approached and the stream is badly needed by many.

OUR ANNUAL EXHIBITION

We are very happy to announce that our annual exhibition will take place at our usual time next Fall (November 3rd), and we are sure it will be a success.

The Exhibition Committee have already begun their preparations and they have displayed in securing the necessary funds to offer suitable prizes. What they have done emerges now, however, and we are sure that their efforts will be rewarded. The Exhibition Committee has been working hard to secure funds and we are very pleased to say that they have been very successful.

WAR CLAMS

From our despatches it will be seen that the clamor for the balance of the war claims has been answered by the first Commission appointed by the Government. We do not know how much of this money will find its way into this district, but certainly it will be very popular, so the water is being approached and the stream is badly needed by many.

THE SASKATCHEWAN

The Battlefield Herald says today—

"An interception of the irrigation canal by the breaking through of the new channel of the Saskatchewan at the Cut Bank should be prevented by vigorous prosecution of the proposed improvements on both sides."

A correspondent of the paper says—

"It is said that the river could be easily kept in its channel by driving piles in the river bed, thus raising the level of the water and forming an embankment that would contain the water and keep it within proper limits. Also, the banks would need to be raised so that the river would not be able to encroach upon the lands of the neighboring farmers."

A Masonic Poem.

The Level and the Square.

We meet upon the Level and we meet upon
the Square.

The words of prayers meaning those
words Masons are.

We meet upon the Level and we meet upon
the Square.

We meet upon the Level though every man
is brought.

The Master's word is law, the Master's word
is law.

We walk upright in Virtue's way and lead
no other hand.

And when we meet we are as one, as one,
we enter the conquered door.

We stand upon the Pinnacle as our Master's
great command.

We walk upright in Virtue's way and lead
no other hand.

And when we meet we are as one, as one,
we enter the conquered door.

We meet upon the Square for the world
is round.

We mingle with the multitude, but keep
our secret work.

For though our meetings in mystery are
great,

And though we meet the Lord to raise the
happy scene.

There's a word where all are equal, we
must not talk fast.

We shall meet upon the Level there when
the time is come.

We shall stand before the Tribunal, and our
Master will be there.

Then we shall have three lives to prove
with God's answering Square.

We'll meet upon the Level there, but never
more.

There's a common height and gloriousness
for the Master.

There's an everlasting welcome for the best
believing there.

What a joy to meet the Lord and been tried
upon the Square.

Let us meet upon the Level then, with
brotherly love and cheer.

So you're kicking about your village paper being so dry, are you? We'd
rather see it blame for less.

Can you think of anything more important happening
this week that was not in the paper? No,
you don't know as you can, but then it
is my paper, and I'm going to tell you
soons. That is the editor's business, he
gets paid for it. Ha! ha! ha! That's
one good one, isn't it? You can't say
that about your paper, can you? Can't
get over it, can you? Good joke on the
editor. Guess he'll be careful next
time he goes out with you in future. But say, friend,
don't you ever stop to think that the village
paper is only a weekly affair, and that
you will let it be? You buy a new
house and put up a house, and see how quickly
the paper will go down the drain, and
if you knew how to fix things up, you
would be good at it. Buy a lot on Third
street and put up a three story brick
block with glass fronts on the ground floor,
office, residence, on the second and third
floors. If you could do that, the village
paper will tell the world what a ter-
rific man you are, and how far
seeing you are to put your money
where your mouth is. Being a big
terror, but prove a grand ornament to the
town, and set the Legislature or Con-
gress, and see if they don't come and
tell the people all it knows about you.
Has your great grandmother used to
sell milk? Has your great grandmother
ever been a rag-picker, and how many of your rel-
atives have been hanged or sent to Congress?
If so, you may plant your paper in the
junkyard and forget it. But say, friend,
are you seeking honors, and that
the people will vote to elect you to sit
in the house of Assembly? Buy a
play 100, and see if the paper don't call
you a public spirited philanthropist, who
will help the poor and needy? You
will do his fellowmen most good. Yes,
the village is just what you make it, and
if you don't make it, why help it least.

—Dundas N.Y. Herald.

The Hudson Bay Railroad schedule is
still somewhat in doubt. High Sather
lastly stated telegram was that he was
shipping rails on Saturday and that work
would begin on Monday, he making the
following day.

TERRITORIAL NEWS.

The Lethbridge News says:

A rumor is current in town that a
party of six Indians who left the reserve
on Tuesday last, have gone on a
hunting expedition, left in search
of game. With whom they had a
party of Crows with whom they had a
friendly intercourse. The Indians
were superior hunters of the Crows and
came upon and returned to camp. An
Indian party of seventy-five which left
here some days ago, has not been heard
from, and it is feared they have
been annihilated. We understand
Crows have been seen near the reserve,
which will be the latter part of this
week, a party of 200 still leaving
behind. We give this information
as a man just in from the Blood camp
and says it is worth, as we are
unable at the present writing to find out
anything more reliable.

The Calgary Tribune says:

Mr. Robert Thomson, Mr. Moses, S. A.
Smith and R. L. Baker were engaged
putting up hay in one of the township
fields of this place this morning. A lynx
crossing the road in front of them was
working. Seeing his rile Mr. Smith
started to pursue. Seeing him advance
the lynx started to run, stopping in
the grass as if to hiding. He drew
nearer to the animal it crouched lower
to the ground, raising his head and
paws and only its tawny tail was vis-
ible above the grass. When about 15
feet away the lynx raised his rile and
ran about 30 feet away. Mr. Smith
said, "I'll bet you a V you dare not take
a step from your shoulder and walk up
to the animal." Mr. Smith then stepped
back, and lowering the rile he stepped
up to the animal. With within a few
feet of the animal Mr. Smith fired a
lightning bound, setting its jaws firmly
by into his shoulder, and endeavoring
to pull it off. Mr. Smith dropped his rile
he seized it by the neck with
both hands and succeeded in holding
its head down, raising it at a considerable
distance from its body. The animal
struggled violently, but Mr. Smith
maintained his hold until the animal
was killed.

THE VERY LATEST NEWS BY WIRE.

(By Special Telegraph.)

Winnipeg, Sept. 29.—A dispatch from Wood Mountain this morning says a party of half breeds just arrived from Fort Belcourt has been killed in a fight between Gros Ventres and Piegans Indians, immediately south of the line. It appears that a number of extra police had been going on guard there some time. Parties from each tribe met in the neighborhood of the line on Saturday, when a fight of two hours duration ensued. Six Piegans were killed, the victims being cut down from three places. It is feared further trouble will be the result.

James Morrison, of Ogema, consulted a doctor who said a gunshot wound.

House meet at Winnipeg took place this week. A large number of outside house have been opened.

P. R. Pringle, of this city, has been offered the Conservative nomination for the local house.

An order by council approved on Sat. under No. 1 Canada Order, amending previous resolution extending the close season for whitefish in Massey Lake and the North West River, from October 1st to November 16th in each year; both days inclusive; for pickerel from April 1st to May 31st; for trout from September 1st to October 1st to January 1st; and for sturgeon from May 1st to June 1st.

Mayor Piggott in going to England to attend the Imperial Exhibition the Regina and Long Lake Railroad.

It was announced at the department of the North West that the four forts now being built down from the North West as a sample to be forwarded to the country, Col. Macdonald having again stated they are best adapted for military purposes in Hudson Bay.

The Globe's Ottawa correspondent says it seems to be arranged that Judge Brooks, ex-M.P.P. for Stanhope, will be appointed Lieutenant Governor of the North West in place of Lord Dufferin, who will probably be appointed Governor of British Columbia.

The fight between John L. Sullivan and Herold of Philadelphia, was stopped by the police on the second round on Saturday. Sullivan won by a unanimous decision.

The fight between John L. Sullivan and Herold of Philadelphia, was stopped by the police on the third round on Saturday. Sullivan won by a unanimous decision.

Serious rioting occurred in Belfast yesterday. The police firing on the mobs, wounding several persons killing three.

The new Lord Lieutenant arrived in Dublin on Saturday. He was received with cheers and groans.

The Lord Mayor of London sent a letter to the Lord Mayor of London, suggesting an exhibition of the Queen's garden at the Crystal Palace. The proposal was made at the London and Indian Exhibition on the basis of the present exhibition, with the promotion of emigration and the expansion of commerce.

Hanlon said for England on Saturday.

In the race on Saturday Beach immediately got a straight lead, pulling thirty-six seconds to the minute to Thunberg's thirty-five and a quarter. Beach was then killed by the third of a length. Beach spotted at the half mile tree, met by half a length. Beach won by three lengths ahead of Thunberg. Beach was three lengths behind the leading horse.

Thunberg's time was 5:56 and Gardner's time 9:02.

At Bathie Gardens began to decrease his appearance. Beach appeared to be only half a length behind. By the time Thunberg Croft was reached Thunberg was held a short distance behind. Thunberg was still slightly in lead. Beach then stopped racing and Thunberg gained back a lead of two lengths.

At Harrow Bridge Beach appeared to be going for the front, won by four lengths. Beach's time was eighteen minutes and twenty seconds. Beach was fearfully hard race throughout. The weather was clear and cold.

Winnipeg, Sept. 29.—On Thursday, the 18th of November, has been appointed Thanksgiving Day.

With few exceptions the claims of various parties concerned in the recent rebellion and others entitled to land grants have been adjusted. The delay in settling the claims of the latter is owing to the difficulty in getting records names of those entitled to bounty.

The Agricultural Society has completed buying electricity at a cost of several hundred dollars for war losses incurred by the members of the society. The first half to be used will be located at the Royal Agricultural Hall.

The Ontario Provincial Exhibition opened in Toronto yesterday.

The Liberal government has been re-elected. The "Black Watch" regiment was sworn.

The Imperial Parliament will be presided over by Mr. Disraeli, who has been elected Speaker.

A cabbler was arrested from London for selling newspapers.

A statement was made by the Board of Trade, saying that the government was unable to pay its bills.

In this emergency the local government was applied to be realized. The government was unable to pay its debts.

Delegates from the Irish Land and Presbyterian Unions will make a visit to Winnipeg.

TOWN COUNCIL.

The Council met on Monday evening, consisting of Messrs. Kelly, Reid, Carter, Richardson, Goddard and Brown.

The minutes of the last meeting were read and adopted.

Correspondence—Minutes of the last meeting were received from Mr. C. M. Brown.
